text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on April 13 in history:
1059 - Pope Nicholas II issued a decree on the election of popes, declaring that only cardinals would be allowed to elect them.
1598 - Henry IV of France promulgated the Edict of Nantes, granting Huguenots equal rights with Catholics.
1605 - Boris Feodorovich Godunov, Tsar of Russia, died and was succeeded by Theodore II.
1732 - Lord North, British Prime Minister from 1770-82, born; his tax on tea provoked U.S. colonists into the "Boston Tea Party" and his policies ultimately led to Britain's loss of America.
1742 - The first performance of Handel's "Messiah" was held in Dublin.
1743 - Thomas Jefferson, American statesman and third president from 1801-09, born. He was a principal author of the Declaration of Independence.
1771 - Richard Trevithick, British inventor and designer of steam engines, born; he was one of the main contributors to the development of the railway steam engine.
1848 - Sicily declared its independence from Naples.
1852 - Frank Winfield Woolworth, American merchant who founded the stores that bear his name, born.
1862 - The Treaty of Shanghai was signed by France and Annam annexing the province of Cochinchina to France. Annam was an empire in what is now Vietnam.
1892 - Arthur "Bomber" Harris, British wartime commander, born. Controversy still surrounds his tactic of "carpet-bombing" enemy cities including Cologne, Berlin and Dresden.
1906 - Samuel Beckett, Irish playwright, poet and critic, born. He lived mostly in France and is noted for his "En attendant Godot" ("Waiting for Godot").
1913 - An assassination attempt on King Alphonso XIII of Spain by an anarchist failed.
1917 - Howard Keel, American singer and actor, born as Harold Clifford Leek. He appeared in singing and acting roles in films from 1948-68 and also appeared on TV in "Dallas".
1919 - The Amritsar massacre took place when British troops shot nearly 380 of Gandhi's followers.
1922 - John Braine, English author, born. One of the 1950s "angry young men", he was a librarian until the success of "Room at the Top" allowed him to write full-time.
1932 - In Germany, the government banned the Nazi paramilitary groups SS and SA.
1935 - The London to Australia airline service was introduced by Imperial Airways and Qantas.
1945 - Vienna, the first foreign capital to be occupied by Hitler, was liberated by the Russians under Fedor Tolbukhin.
1945 - Massive firebombing raids by Allied bombers destroyed a large part of Tokyo.
1962 - After February elections, Ahti Karjalainen became the youngest prime minister of Finland.
1963 - Gary Kasparov, Russian chess player and world champion, born.
1964 - Winston Field resigned from Premiership of Southern Rhodesia and was succeeded by Ian Smith.
1966 - Abdul Salam Arif, president of Iraq, was killed in a helicopter crash.
1968 - Tanzania became the first country to recognise the Nigerian secessionist state of Biafra as a sovereign nation.
1975 - A military coup in Chad overthrew President Ngarta Tombaloaye, who was killed. Felix Malloum took over at the head of a seven-member junta.
1975 - Christian militiamen in Lebanon killed 22 Palestinians on a bus in the Ain er-Rummaineh suburb of Beirut. This attack is generally accepted as the starting point of the Lebanese Civil War.
1982 - U.S. Secretary of State Alexander Haig returned to Washington after failed attempts in London and Buenos Aires to settle the Falkland Islands dispute.
1989 - Israeli police opened fire on Palestinians from the village of Nahalin, killing four.
1990 - The Soviet Union admitted for the first time that it was responsible for the 1940 massacre of thousands of Polish officers at Katyn, Poland.
1994 - Belgian paratroopers evacuated the last foreigners from Kigali as rebels tightened their grip around the central African capital ravaged by days of tribal bloodshed.
1996 - Brussels conference of aid donors for Bosnia ended with a pledge to donate 1.23 billion dollars to rebuild the country.
